summary.title: Executive Summary
summary.description: Forge Protocol is a framework for building AI systems across security boundaries. It tracks every code change, every review, every approval - creating a complete provenance chain from requirements to deployment. When integrated with Guardian Protocol, it enables complete accountability: from the developer who wrote the code to the operator who made the lethal decision.
summary.sister_protocol: Sister Protocol: Guardian Protocol handles operational accountability (runtime decisions). Forge Protocol handles development accountability (who built this rule?).

problem.title: The Challenge: Who Built This Rule?

items.title: Problem 1: Clearance Paradox
items.description: Senior developer (CONFIDENTIAL clearance) receives requirement: 'Implement SECRET algorithm from specification doc-00423.' Cannot read spec → Cannot implement correctly → System is unsafe.

items.title: Problem 2: Data Diode Gap
items.description: AI trained on SECRET data in Red Forge. Must test performance → Data OUT of Red Forge → Security breach.

items.title: Problem 3: Standards Compliance Gap
items.description: FMV requires proof of EU AI Act compliance. Development team has documentation in Word/PDF → FMV auditor must manually correlate requirements → 4 hours review per incident.

items.title: Problem 4: Provenance Loss
items.description: Security incident → Investigation needs to know 'Who changed this parameter? Why? Was it approved?' → Git log lacks context → Inconclusive investigation.

items.title: Problem 5: Operational Accountability Gap
items.description: Wrongful kill occurs → Guardian Protocol shows operator authorized engagement → But WHO BUILT THE RULE the system used? Development provenance is missing.

components.title: 1. Red Forge Architecture
components.description: Secure environment for classified AI development. SECRET data never leaves Red Forge (data diode IN only), test metrics can be exported (no secrets), developers get feedback for iteration without seeing classified data.

components.title: 2. Classification-Aware Development
components.description: Developers with different clearances collaborate without leakage. CONFIDENTIAL developers see filtered specifications with SECRET sections removed. SECRET spec writers work in Red Forge with full detail.

components.title: 3. Standards-as-Graphs
components.description: EU AI Act requirements stored as queryable graphs (Neo4j). Instead of manual PDF review, FMV auditors can run Cypher queries for immediate compliance validation. Automatic deployment gates prevent deployment without complete proof.

components.title: 4. Git Provenance Tracking (MCP Integration)
components.description: Every code change tracked with complete context: who changed what, why, confidence level, AI vs. human contribution percentage, review cycles, compliance links. Cryptographically signed commits create immutable audit trail.

components.title: 5. Guardian Protocol Integration
components.description: When Guardian Protocol logs a lethal decision, it references the rule/code version (git commit hash). Forge provenance shows who authored, reviewed, approved that rule. Complete chain: developer → certifier → operator → commander.

accountability.title: Development Accountability Chain
accountability.description: Every rule, every algorithm, every parameter traces to named individuals:

example.title: Investigation Example
example.incident: Guardian Protocol logs: Rule #47b engaged target

forge_traces.data: Rule #47b: 'Engage armed combatants <100m' → Dr. Andersson (Guardian Tech AB) → Commit a3f4e9c → 2025-11-23 14:32 UTC
Military SME review: Maj. Bergström (added safety constraints) → 2025-11-24 → 'Reduced range to 100m, added IFF check'
JAG review: Lt. Kravchenko → 2025-11-25 → 'Compliant with ROE, proportionality assessment required'
AI generated: 60% (Claude Sonnet 3.5) → Human modified: 40% (safety constraints, legal compliance)
FMV approval: 2025-12-01 → Linked to EU AI Act requirement #A4.2 → Certificate #FMV-SE-2025-1547

guardian_traces.data: System deployed: Col. Petrov → 2026-01-10 08:23 → Sector 4, anti-drone mission
Mission parameters: Capt. Volkov → 2026-01-10 06:15 → Rules #45-#52 active
Dire circumstances override: Capt. Volkov → 2026-01-15 04:47:34 → Rule #47b invoked → Enhanced audit triggered

example.complete_chain: Dr. Andersson (author) → Maj. Bergström (reviewer) → Lt. Kravchenko (JAG) → FMV (certifier) → Col. Petrov (commander) → Capt. Volkov (operator)

integration.title: Forge + Guardian = Complete Accountability
integration.forge: Forge Protocol: Who built this rule? Who reviewed it? Who approved it?
integration.guardian: Guardian Protocol: Who deployed it? Who configured it? Who invoked it?
integration.together: Together: Complete audit trail from code authorship to operational lethal decision.
integration.benefit: No 'fog of war.' No 'the system did it.' Every decision traces to named individuals at every level.

sectors.title: For Defense Industry
sectors.problem: Developing AI systems across security boundaries requires expensive, separate teams for each clearance level → Slow iteration, difficult collaboration. No clear provenance for investigations.
sectors.solution: Classification-aware development + complete git provenance + Guardian integration. Every rule traces from author to operator.
sectors.benefit: Faster time-to-market, lower development costs, complete accountability for investigations.

sectors.title: For NATO DIANA Startups
sectors.problem: Need SÄPO approval (€50K, 6 months) for classified AI development → Cannot compete with established players. No provenance tracking infrastructure.
sectors.solution: Share Red Forge environment (Classified Development as a Service), built-in provenance tracking, Guardian integration ready.
sectors.benefit: Faster innovation (iteration from day 1), lower entry cost (€5K/month vs. €50K capex), provable accountability.

sectors.title: For Procurement Authorities (FMV, NATO)
sectors.problem: Auditing autonomous weapons development requires manual correlation of requirements, code, tests, approvals → 4 hours per incident. Operational incidents lack development context.
sectors.solution: Standards-as-Graphs + Git provenance + Guardian integration. Query 'Show me: who built Rule #47b, who reviewed it, when was it certified, where is it deployed?'
sectors.benefit: Instant audit queries, complete accountability chain, faster procurement decisions.
